body: I am getting this as well.

I just updated last night, and I have already experienced multiple crashes this morning.  Thankfully, TMUX has my back:

```
tmux attach-session -t 0
```

...and I'm back in business where I left off.
@jrop Im using tmux too, but sometimes alacritty crashes 5 times in a row, i might have to revert to using the built in terminal until this is fixed.

I finally caught the problem report from the most recent crash.  Interestingly, Alacritty has always crashed when I have had Chrome focused.  However, I am unsure if this is going to remain true.

Is this a recent change? I haven't heard about this before and now a couple of people seem to be having that issue.

Alacritty also hasn't been updated recently, so that makes it even weirder. Potentially a faulty macos update? If not maybe downgrading Alacritty helps?

I'm personally interested if `cargo run` produces any output, since that's much more likely to produce a useful backtrace when Alacritty crashes. Though a SIGSEGV is very unrustlike so that strikes me as odd.
@chrisduerr  macos 10.14.4 came out yesterday, so yes that's the recent change. Alacritty was running fine otherwise for the past month.

issue.title: Random, frequent crashes on macOS 10.14.4

repository.name: kitty
repository.description: If you live in the terminal, kitty is made for you! Cross-platform, fast, feature-rich, GPU based.

issue.body: Kitty randomly crashes on the current macOS, recently released (10.14.4).

body:
alacritty also started crashing frequently for me since upgrading to 10.14.4. 

OS X crash report: https://pastebin.com/fp5P2mV8

It looks like 10.14.4 introduced some updates to the graphics drivers of macOS. The SIGSEGV might indicate that there is an issue with drivers.

I'd be interested in knowing which exact hardware this occurs on. Is everyone affected here using genuine Apple hardware? If so, which GPUs are active?

If someone is capable of reproducing this crash and willing to test some things out, changing [this](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/master/src/window.rs#L126) line from `None` to `true` is also worth testing to see if that resolves the crash.

@chrisduerr I am not sure how to see which gfx card is active, although I do see that my Mac supports "automatic switching" (I assume between the built-in Intel chip, and the Radeon).

MacBook Pro (15-inch, 2018)
2.2 GHz Intel Core i7
16 GB 2400 MHz DDR4
Radeon Pro 555X 4 GB Intel UHD Graphics 630 1536 MB

My crashes are on a [MacBookPro11,3](https://everymac.com/systems/apple/macbook_pro/specs/macbook-pro-core-i7-2.5-15-dual-graphics-mid-2014-retina-display-specs.html) with autoswitching between a GeForce GT 750M and a Intel Iris 5200 Pro graphics processor.

```
   Compiling alacritty v0.2.9 (src/alacritty)
error[E0308]: mismatched types
   --> src/window.rs:126:37
    |
126 |         .with_hardware_acceleration(true)
    |                                     ^^^^
    |                                     |
    |                                     expected enum `std::option::Option`, found bool
    |                                     help: try using a variant of the expected type: `ansi::_IMPL_DESERIALIZE_FOR_CursorStyle::_serde::export::Some(true)`
    |
    = note: expected type `std::option::Option<bool>`
               found type `bool`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
error: Could not compile `alacritty`.
```
Oh, my bad. It needs to be changed to `Some(true)`, not just `true`.

ok that works.

I can use the [gfxCardStatus](https://gfx.io/) app to switch between integrated and discrete GPUs, which repeatably forces a crash in Alacritty.

```
RUST_BACKTRACE=1 /Applications/Alacritty.app/Contents/MacOS/alacritty 
2019-03-28 21:11:22.713 alacritty[7690:771184] *** Assertion failure in -[NSCGLSurface flushRect:], /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/AppKit/AppKit-1671.40.119/OpenGL.subproj/NSCGLSurface.m:569
thread 'main' panicked at 'called `Option::unwrap()` on a `None` value', src/libcore/option.rs:345:21
stack backtrace:
   0: std::sys::unix::backtrace::tracing::imp::unwind_backtrace
   1: std::panicking::default_hook::{{closure}}
   2: std::panicking::rust_panic_with_hook
   3: std::panicking::continue_panic_fmt
   4: rust_begin_unwind
   5: core::panicking::panic_fmt
   6: core::panicking::panic
   7: main
fatal runtime error: failed to initiate panic, error 5
Abort trap: 6
```
Here's another one:
```
RUST_BACKTRACE=1 /Applications/Alacritty.app/Contents/MacOS/alacritty 
2019-03-28 21:13:45.753 alacritty[7846:772667] *** Assertion failure in -[NSCGLSurface flushRect:], /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/AppKit/AppKit-1671.40.119/OpenGL.subproj/NSCGLSurface.m:569
Segmentation fault: 11
```
And another:
```

```
So it only crashes on the integrated GPU, or only on the dedicated one?

Carsh on switching in either direction.

So as a summary, it crashes when it's `None`, or it crashes when it's `Some(true)` and you switch the GPU? However when using `Some(true)` without switching it always works?

It would also be interesting if this is caused by Alacritty's OpenGL code, or by the windowing library Alacritty is using.

So if someone could verify if https://github.com/tomaka/glutin works, that would be nice. Once cloned, it can be tested using `cargo run --example window`.

With "Some(true)" it crashed switching GPUs, in either direction.

I can check whether the standard build does the same later today. (Or
someone else on this thread can.)
